extracted_concepts.definition: The fundamental unit of time during combat, representing a quick, dynamic period where every participant takes a turn.

rule_logic.implication: All participants take one turn; the round lasts approximately 6 seconds in the game world
rule_logic.description_text: The game organizes the chaos of combat into a cycle of rounds. In a round, each participant in a battle takes a turn. The order of turns is determined at the beginning of combat, when everyone rolls initiative. Every round represents about 6 seconds in the game world.
related_search_terms: how long is a combat round

extracted_concepts.definition: A standard unit of time, equivalent to 60 seconds.

rule_logic.premise: When measuring time, especially in relation to combat rounds
rule_logic.implication: One minute is equivalent to 10 combat rounds
rule_logic.description_text: A minute is composed of 60 seconds. Given that a combat round is 6 seconds, a minute is equal to 10 combat rounds.
related_search_terms: how many rounds in a minute

extracted_concepts.definition: A standard unit of time, equivalent to 60 minutes.

rule_logic.premise: When measuring time for longer durations
rule_logic.implication: One hour is equivalent to 60 minutes or 600 combat rounds
rule_logic.description_text: An hour is made up of 60 minutes.

extracted_concepts.definition: A standard unit of time, equivalent to 24 hours.

rule_logic.premise: When measuring time for daily cycles or events
rule_logic.implication: One day is equivalent to 24 hours

extracted_concepts.definition: The typical unit of time measurement for adventuring activities within a dungeon environment.

rule_logic.premise: GM determines time for a task AND context is a dungeon environment
rule_logic.implication: Time is tracked on a scale of minutes
rule_logic.description_text: In a dungeon environment, the adventurers' movement happens on a scale of minutes. It takes them about a minute to creep down a long hallway, another minute to check for traps on the door at the end of the hall, and a good ten minutes to search the chamber beyond for anything interesting or valuable.
related_search_terms: how long to search a room

extracted_concepts.concept_name: City and Wilderness Travel Time Scale
extracted_concepts.definition: The typical unit of time measurement for travel and activities in city or wilderness environments.

rule_logic.premise: GM determines time for a task AND context is a city or wilderness environment
rule_logic.implication: Time is tracked on a scale of hours
rule_logic.description_text: In a city or wilderness, a scale of hours is often more appropriate. Adventurers eager to reach the lonely tower at the heart of the forest hurry across those fifteen miles in just under four hours' time.

extracted_concepts.definition: The typical unit of time measurement for extended travel over long distances.

rule_logic.premise: GM determines time for a task AND context is a long journey
rule_logic.implication: Time is tracked on a scale of days
rule_logic.description_text: For long journeys, a scale of days works best. Following the road from Baldur's Gate to Waterdeep, the adventurers spend four uneventful days before a goblin ambush interrupts their journey.

extracted_concepts.definition: A specific unit of time used for fast-paced situations, particularly combat.

rule_logic.premise: GM determines time for a task AND context is combat or other fast-paced situations
rule_logic.implication: Time is tracked in rounds, where each round is a 6-second span
rule_logic.description_text: In combat and other fast-paced situations, the game relies on rounds, a 6-second span of time.
